did.abstract: Constitutions, minutes, correspondence, lecturers' files, and publicity material; include correspondence, 1890-1896, of Thomas C. Trueblood and James B. Angell relating to the establishment of the association

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The papers were donated by Mrs. Lucille Upham (Donor No. 3799) in 1961 and 1962. Additional files came from a storage room in the University's Administration Building in 1984. The provenance of this last accession is not certain.

accruals.p: No further additions to the records expected.

accessrestrict.p: The records are open without restriction.

userestrict.p: Copyright status of the material is uncertain.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Oratorical Association (University of Michigan) records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The University of Michigan Oratorical Association was formally initiated in 1912, although the tradition of bringing lecturers to speak on campus had been long established. As early as 1824, the University was visited by itinerant speakers, and in 1854 the Student Lecture Association was formed. As its name suggests, this was a student-run organization whose purpose was to bring lecturers to the University. This was in contrast to the faculty-sponsored Oratorical Association, organized by Professor-Emeritus Thomas Trueblood in 1889. The latter organization was essentially a debating society, but it took on the form and function of the Student Lecture Association when that group went bankrupt in 1912.

The lectures themselves covered a broad spectrum of interests. Some of the early speakers included Horace Greeley, Victoria Woodhull, Mark Twain, and P.T. Barnum. Later speakers, such as Eleanor Roosevelt, Admiral Byrd, Margaret Bourke-White and Ogden Nash continued this tradition of widely varied lecture topics. Some spoke on serious political issues of the day, or important scientific discoveries, while still others simply entertained.
By the early 1960s, however, interest in the lecture series had waned. At some point in time, probably around 1961, the Oratorical Association quietly collapsed, due to lack of interest.

scopecontent.p: The papers of the University of Michigan Oratorical Association consist of nearly three linear feet of material. The collection is organized in five series: History, Minutes, Correspondence, Name File and Publicity

The uses of this collection are rather limited. Probably only researchers of the University of Michigan's history will find it of any value. Even then, the quality of the material here is low, consisting as it does primarily of newspaper clippings which are readily obtainable elsewhere. Although the Oratorical Association made use of many notable figures of the day, neither the Correspondence nor the Name-file yield unique information about these people. Possibly the only thing this collection reflects is the changing public taste in entertainment.

The series History documents the life of the organization in a rather sketchy fashion. This small series is divided into a "general" section, "Applications for Lectures," "Centennial" (of the University of Michigan), "Constitutions," and "Lists of Lectures." The latter gives listings as early as 1855.
Minutes is probably the most intriguing series in the collection. it covers the years 1916-1934, and better than any other material shows the workings of the Oratorical Association itself.

The third series is Correspondence, which is somewhat larger than History. The series is arranged chronologically, and spans the years 1890-1961. Most of the correspondence concerns the detail of arranging for speakers to come to the University, negotiations with agents, and so forth.

The fourth series, the Name File, is easily the largest in the collection. Arranged alphabetically, the series consists of files on the various speakers and performers who were part of the Oratorical Association's lecture series. Each file consists primarily of newspaper clippings advertising or reporting on the lectures and performances. The time span covered is roughly 1939-1960.

The Publicity series in some ways mirrors the contents of the Name File. However, it is arranged chronologically, and while it too is mainly Made up of newspaper clippings, these usually deal with the entire lecture series of a given year rather than with individual performances. It documents the years 1926-1961 with only a couple of gaps in the sequence.
The Photographs series includes pictures of he Oratorical Board and of debating teams whose activities were administered under the auspices of the Oratorical Association.
